claim_text: Long-duration spaceflight causes a ~54% increase in red blood cell hemolysis resulting in space anemia
context: Trudel et al. 2022 (Nature Medicine). 14 ISS astronauts, 6-month missions. Stable isotope breath test.
R_reasoning: Trudel 2022 + Twin Study partial confirmation; small n
C_reasoning: ISS long-duration only; lunar/shorter missions unknown
M_reasoning: Prospective, validated method, but small n
notes: SB-002,spaceflight_biology,Cosmic radiation exposure during deep-space missions increases the risk of cataract in astronauts"
column18: Epidemiological study from Cucinotta et al. and multiple NASA longitudinal studies. N~35 Apollo-era + ISS.
column25: Multiple NASA cohorts confirm elevated cataract rates in astronauts
column26: Specific to high-dose deep-space radiation; LEO risk lower
column27: Retrospective, self-reported, dosimetry uncertain; adequate n for rare endpoint
column29: Finding established 1990s-2010s; consistent across multiple cohort waves
column31: SB-003,spaceflight_biology,Orthostatic intolerance upon return from long-duration spaceflight occurs in >80% of astronauts"
column32: Multi-center physiological assessments post-ISS mission across US and Russian programs.
column39: Confirmed across NASA, Roscosmos, ESA post-flight assessments
column40: Long-duration ISS specific; Shuttle (2-week) showed less severe effects
column41: Standardized tilt-table tests, multiple missions, moderate n
column43: Established finding since Mir program; consistent across 20+ years
column45: SB-004,spaceflight_biology,Fluid shift to the upper body in microgravity causes neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS) in ~70% of long-duration ISS crewmembers"
column46: NASA SANS studies, Johnson Space Center. Pre/post MRI imaging, IOP measurements. N~100+ crewmembers.
column53: Confirmed in multiple NASA cohort studies; mechanism debated
column54: ISS specific (6-month); shorter missions poorly characterized
column55: Pre/post MRI standardized; adequate n for spaceflight research
column56: MRI structural + IOP + OCT concordant; proteomics limited
column57: Identified 2010s; interpretation evolving as mechanism debated
column59: SB-005,spaceflight_biology,TNFSF11 (RANKL) is significantly upregulated in cfRNA from astronaut blood during spaceflight"
column60: NASA Twin Study cfRNA analysis, Scott and Mark Kelly. N=1 twin pair.
column67: Single twin pair; not independently replicated
column68: Single pair, extreme individual variability, unvalidated in other crewmembers
column69: N=1 limits generalizability; cfRNA method was novel at time
column70: Transcriptomic + some protein data concordant in this pair
column71: 2019 Twin Study; no replication in larger crews since
column73:
Extreme n=1 caveat; treat as hypothesis-generating
CG-001,cancer_genomics,KRAS G12C mutation in NSCLC predicts sensitivity to sotorasib with ORR ~37% in pretreated patients"
column74: CodeBreaK100 Phase I/II (Skoulidis et al. NEJM 2021) and CodeBreaK200 Phase III (de Langen et al. NEJM 2023).
column81: Phase I/II + Phase III RCT; FDA approved 2021; multiple sites
column82: KRAS G12C-specific; CRC shows lower ORR (~7%); lung-predominant
column83: Gold-standard RCT; pre-registered; large n; regulatory-standard
column84: Clinical drug sensitivity; no multi-omics measurement
column87: CG-002,cancer_genomics,TP53 mutation is present in approximately 50% of human solid tumors"
column88: TCGA pan-cancer analysis and COSMIC database (>1 million tumor sequences).
column95: TCGA, COSMIC, ICGC, numerous independent studies; textbook fact
column96: Frequency varies by tumor type (>90% ovarian HGSOC; <10% CLL); 50% is population average
column97: Pan-cancer databases, massive n, validated sequencing methods
column99: Known since 1989 (Lane & Crawford); TCGA 2013 confirmed at scale
column101: CG-003,cancer_genomics,BRCA1 pathogenic variants confer a 65-72% lifetime breast cancer risk"
column102: Prospective studies (Chen et al. 2007; Antoniou et al. 2003) and large consortium meta-analyses (BRCA1/2 Cohort Consortium).
column109: Multiple large prospective cohorts; consortium meta-analyses; well-established
column110: Risk estimate varies by variant type, modifier genes, ethnicity; population-specific
column111: Large n prospective cohorts; validated penetrance modeling; some ascertainment bias
column113: Established 2000s; estimates refined but broadly consistent
column115:
Risk estimates vary 55-75% across studies depending on population
CG-004,cancer_genomics,EGFR exon 19 deletion and L858R mutations predict erlotinib sensitivity in advanced NSCLC"
column116: Multiple RCTs (OPTIMAL, ENSURE, EURTAC trials) and meta-analyses across Asian and European populations.
column123: Multiple RCTs across populations; FDA approved 2004; textbook molecular oncology
column124: EGFR-mutant NSCLC specific; de novo resistance known; minor EGFR mutations not covered
column125: Gold-standard RCTs; pre-registered; stratified by biomarker
column127: Finding established 2004-2010; consistent with multiple generation of EGFR inhibitors
column129: CG-005,cancer_genomics,Pan-cancer cfDNA liquid biopsy achieves >99% specificity but <50% overall sensitivity for early-stage cancer detection"
column130: CancerSEEK (Cohen et al. Science 2018) and Galleri/GRAIL multi-cancer detection studies.
column137: CancerSEEK confirmed; Galleri PATHFINDER study partially confirmed; technology evolving
column138: High specificity consistent; sensitivity improves with stage, varies greatly by cancer type
column139: Large n prospective studies; adequate power for sensitivity/specificity
column140: Genomic (mutations) + protein biomarkers combined in some studies
column141: Rapid field evolution 2018-2024; sensitivity figures improving with newer approaches
column143:
Sensitivity estimates improving rapidly; 2018 figures may underestimate current performance
NS-001,neuroscience,Adult hippocampal neurogenesis is substantially diminished in humans compared to other mammals"
column144: Sorrells et al. Nature 2018 vs Boldrini et al. Cell Stem Cell 2018 — directly contradictory findings.
column151: Two high-profile papers in 2018 directly contradict each other; field unresolved
column152: Specific to human adult hippocampus; rodent neurogenesis well-established
column153: Post-mortem tissue; antibody specificity disputed; fixation artifacts debated; small n
column157:
Classic contested finding; useful for training annotators on low-confidence claims
NS-002,neuroscience,Dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens mediates reward prediction error signaling"
column158: Schultz et al. (1997) seminal work and decades of confirmation across species using microdialysis, optogenetics, and fiber photometry.
column165: Confirmed by Schultz 1997, hundreds of electrophysiology, optogenetics, photometry studies
column166: Demonstrated in rodents, primates, and humans (fMRI BOLD proxy); mechanism conserved
column167: Gold-standard electrophysiology, optogenetics (causal), imaging; multiple species
column168: Electrophysiology + optogenetics + imaging + transcriptomics (DA neuron identity) concordant
column169: Established 1997; expanded and refined but core finding consistent
column171: NS-003,neuroscience,Amyloid-beta plaques are the primary causal driver of Alzheimer's disease neurodegeneration"
column172: Amyloid Cascade Hypothesis (Hardy & Selkoe, 2002). Multiple clinical trials of anti-amyloid therapies.
column179: Supported by genetic evidence (APP, PSEN); contradicted by failure of anti-amyloid trials and Lesne data concerns (2006 Nature paper)
column180: Causal claim disputed; plaques correlate with pathology but tau tangles and neuroinflammation may be primary drivers
column181: Genetic evidence strong; clinical trial evidence weak (failures of aducanumab, etc.); lecanemab shows modest benefit
column182: Amyloid imaging + CSF biomarkers + genetics + proteomics partially concordant but tau/amyloid relationship complex
column183: Hypothesis dominant since 1992; support eroded 2010-2022; partial rehabilitation with lecanemab 2023
column185:
The Lesne 2006 retraction concerns weaken key mechanistic evidence; field in active revision
NS-004,neuroscience,Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are more effective than placebo for treating major depressive disorder in moderate-to-severe cases"
column186: Cipriani et al. Lancet 2018 meta-analysis of 522 trials, 116,000+ patients.
column193: 522 RCTs; largest meta-analysis to date; consistent effect sizes
column194: Benefit concentrated in moderate-to-severe depression; mild depression effect debated; heterogeneity across SSRIs
column195: Large RCT pool; publication bias corrected (funnel plot); robust meta-analytic methods
column197: Decades of data; 2018 Cipriani re-established consensus after Kirsch 2008 controversy
column199:
Effect size modest (SMD ~0.3); clinical vs. statistical significance debate ongoing
NS-005,neuroscience,APOE ε4 allele is the strongest common genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease
column201: GWAS data, ApoE3/E4 functional studies, multiple large cohorts (UK Biobank, ADNI, etc.)
column208: Confirmed across multiple independent GWAS and cohorts; textbook genetic risk factor
column209: Risk varies by sex (greater in women), ethnicity (reduced in West Africans); mechanism partially unclear
column210: Large GWAS, validated in multiple populations, prospective cohorts
column212: Established 1993 (Corder et al.); risk estimates consistent across 30 years
column214: Population-specific risk modification increasingly documented; simple Mendelian risk framing oversimplified
